bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wenceslao Pareja, August 7, 1922

div1.p: Carter thanks Pareja for providing him with historical data on yellow fever cases in Guayaquil and asks him to clarify some statements.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wenceslao Pareja, August 7, 1922
div1.opener:
/LC
Book
Guayaquil
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
August 7, 1922.
Dr. W. Pareja,
Director de Sanidad,
Guayaquil-Ecuador.
My Dear Doctor Pareja:
div1.p:
Please accept my thanks for the data you sent me of the yellow
fever in Guayaquil, under date of July 4, 1922.

I had not seen the account of the yellow fever among the pirates, who
attacked Guayaquil in 1709.

The earliest notice I had seen was that of La Condamine y Ulloa
in 1740.

(1) to give me the title of the work of Pedro Fermin Cevallos, as
I may be able to find it in some library here, and

(2) to tell me if the yellow fever aboard the ships of the pirates
in 1709 was supposed to have been contracted from the prisoners taken
at Guayaquil--or in the City of Guayaquil--or had the pirates come from
some infected city--as Panama?

When I get a chance to have a photograph taken I shall be very
happy to send you one, and am much gratified that you should have re-
quested it. I would be very much pleased to have your own in return.
With highest personal regards, and again thanking you for your letter
div1.closer:
Very truly your friend, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
